canons.description: This document defines the normative schema for `.agent` contracts.
This document defines the canonical activation state model for all Maturion systems, subsystems, and capabilities.
This document defines the canonical protocol by which agents maintain currency with canonical governance context through governed, auditable, and deterministic synchronisation.

Canonical governance document: AGENT_CONTRACT_MIGRATION_GUIDE

This protocol establishes protection mechanisms for critical agent contract requirements through locked sections that prevent unauthorized modification, removal, or weakening of governance-critical...
This document defines which canonical governance documents repository `.agent` files MUST or SHOULD bind to, establishing the minimum governance foundation for all repositories.
Canonical governance document: AGENT_ONBOARDING_QUICKSTART
This document defines the only legitimate process by which software agents may be introduced (“recruited”) into the governance system administered by the Foreman.

- Who may recruit which agents in the Maturion ecosystem
- Who may update which `.agent` contract files

This document defines the canonical obligation for all agents to recognize, surface, and communicate ripple effects of their changes.
This document provides explicit, canonical clarification defining which governance gates apply to which agent roles.
This document defines the mandatory contract for how each application declares its unique commissioning and startup requirements in a structured, auditable, and machine-interpretable way.
This document defines the mandatory completeness requirements for all architecture artifacts in the Maturion ecosystem.
This document defines the canonical semantics for human-in-the-loop review of assisted ripple scan reports.
This document defines the canonical scope of assisted ripple scanning within a single repository.
This document defines what it means for a repository to be audit-ready from a governance and compliance perspective.
Canonical governance document: BOOTSTRAP_EXECUTION_LEARNINGS
This canon formally defines branch protection enforcement as a mandatory, governed requirement for all repositories executing governed builds under the One-Time Build philosophy.

This standard defines how Build Effectiveness is computed and reported.
This document defines the canonical model for build interventions, alerts, and attention routing within the Maturion ecosystem.
This document defines the canonical inspection and drill-down model for all build nodes within the Maturion ecosystem.

This document defines the canonical hierarchical structure of builds within the Maturion ecosystem, establishing how work is organized, executed, monitored, and controlled across multiple levels of...

This rule prevents PRs from accumulating non-local failures
that destroy diagnostic clarity.
This canon establishes that CI execution is confirmatory, not diagnostic across all governed repositories.
This document formally defines the Cognitive Capability Orchestration Model for the Maturion ecosystem.
This document formally defines the authority hierarchy and decision rights for the Cognitive Hygiene Protocol (CHP) within the Maturion ecosystem.
This document formally defines how the Cognitive Hygiene Protocol (CHP) interacts with memory systems to ensure memory integrity, proposal-only writes, and zero risk of silent memory mutation.
This document establishes Combined Subwave Testing (CST) and Combined Wave Testing (CWT) as the canonical patterns for strategic integration assurance in multi-wave, one-time builds.
This document defines the canonical evidence model for commissioning and activation of Maturion applications.

This policy defines how Maturion achieves continuous audit readiness and
international standards compliance across the entire build-and-maintain factory.
This document defines the Constitutional Sandbox Pattern: the authoritative model for agent judgment, execution flexibility, and process optimization within governance boundaries.
This document provides operational guidance for applying the Constitutional Sandbox Pattern (BL-024) in wave planning, builder appointment, and execution oversight.

This document defines the canonical model for cross-repository ripple awareness within the Maturion ecosystem.
This canon establishes the mandatory governance framework for resolving defects, performing maintenance, and managing patches for already published builds and production systems.
This document formally defines the delegation instruction protocol and audit model for platform action execution between Foreman (FM) and Maturion.
These rules govern how responsibility domains evolve over time.

This document defines how responsibility domains are held accountable
for architectural completeness and build correctness over time.

This document contains draft language for insertion into agent contract files (`.agent` or `.agent.md`) in future waves.

This document defines the mandatory process for environment variable provisioning in the Maturion build model.
This protocol establishes mandatory execution verification at every phase of FPC (First Point of Contact) repository layer-down and all governance-enforced work.
This protocol establishes the continuous monitoring and enforcement framework for the Execution Bootstrap Protocol across all governed repositories throughout each governance cycle.

This rule ensures that failures that expose governance gaps are formally promoted
into governance change management rather than remaining local knowledge.

This document defines the FM Pre-Authorization Checklist that acts as a mandatory pre-authorization checkpoint for all wave and subwave planning before FM authorizes execution.
This document defines the runtime enforcement and continuous situational awareness mechanisms that ensure FM (Foreman) operates within governance constraints and cannot drift from canonical intent.
This document formally defines the Foreman (FM) as a managerial authority within the Maturion ecosystem, establishing its supervisory responsibilities over builders and the execution process.
This is the First Point of Contact (FPC) document for governance layer-down.

- Dependency-closed
- Audit-structure-ready

This document formally establishes In-Between Wave Reconciliation (IBWR) as a mandatory execution step that occurs after a wave gate PASS and before authorization of the next wave.

This model defines how raw lessons learned from builds,
PR gate failures, QA mismatches, and operational friction
are captured, evaluated, and promoted into governance.

This rule governs how learnings that indicate systemic gaps
are promoted into governance, architecture law, and agent behavior.

To institutionalize continuous improvement across all applications, agents, and builders without disrupting execution or introducing scope creep.

This document formally classifies and defines Maturion-isms as Foundational Conceptual Doctrine within the Maturion governance ecosystem.

This document defines the canonical specification for the Maturion Runtime
Execution Monitor.
This document formally defines Memory Integrity and Corruption Detection requirements for the Maturion ecosystem.
This document formally defines the Memory Lifecycle State Machine required by Foreman (FM) runtime and cognitive hygiene integration.
This document formally defines what Memory State Observability means for Foreman (FM) and Watchdog.

This document formally defines the authority boundary between:
- Foreman (FM) — execution authority within repositories
- Maturion — control-plane authority for platform actions (GitHub)
This canon defines, constitutionally and unambiguously, what it means for the platform to be ready to execute a governed build.

This rule enforces the One-Time Build Law by preventing
handover of builds that do not already satisfy all required PR gates.
This policy prevents cascading failures caused by excessive initial scope.
This document defines the QA-Catalog-Alignment Gate that acts as a mandatory pre-authorization checkpoint for all wave and subwave planning in systems using QA-driven development.
This document defines the mandatory initialization phase for all new application repositories before architecture design or build activities may begin.

that may be declared in a Scope Declaration.

This schema defines the mandatory structure for a Scope Declaration.

This rule enforces alignment between a PR’s declared scope
and the files actually modified in the PR.

Tier-0 constitutional doctrine establishing zero tolerance for technical debt, test failures, errors, and safety violations. Mandates immediate remediation regardless of origin, universal responsibility for quality, and no partial handovers.
This document defines the mandatory protocol for commissioning and progressive activation of any Maturion application.
This document defines governance rules for versioning and evolution of all governance artifacts, application code, and system components.
This document defines vision drift detection requirements for the Independent Watchdog.
This protocol defines the mandatory blocker process when any agent discovers warnings or test debt from prior work (previous jobs, waves, or subwaves).
This document formally defines the Independent Watchdog as a governance observation and escalation system within the Maturion ecosystem.

This policy establishes App Descriptions as mandatory upstream authority artifacts for all applications in the Maturion ecosystem.
This policy defines the CORRECT vs INCORRECT methodology for tracing tests to architectural requirements.
This policy establishes a mandatory automated deprecation detection gate for technical debt prevention across all repositories in the Maturion Engineering Ecosystem.
This policy defines the Builder QA Handover Contract - the canonical requirements for Builder agents to hand over work to the Governance Gate for merge authorization.
